awd_titl_txt: Zoombinis: The Full Development Implementation Research Study of a Computational Thinking Game for Upper Elementary and Middle School Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
The Logical Journey of the Zoombinis implementation research study examines the development of computational thinking for upper elementary and middle grades students. Computational thinking is the set of ideas and practices considered vital for computer science skills and has been attracting increased attention over the past several years in K-12 education. This project leverages an existing game by embedding tools for studying patterns of students' decision-making and problem solving in the environment. This allows researchers to understand how students learn about computational thinking within a tool that bridges informal and formal learning settings to engage a wide variety of students. The project will also develop tools and resources for classroom teachers. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The research examines three questions. First, what strategies do players develop during Zoombinis gameplay that may provide evidence of implicit computational thinking? Second, how can teachers leverage implicit knowledge of computational thinking developed in Zoombinis to improve formal (explicit) learning? Third, how can a large-scale commercial game be used for broad and equitable improvement of computational thinking? The research uses and develops educational data mining techniques to assess students' learning in conjunction with pre-post computational thinking assessments (external to the game), teacher interviews, classroom observations, and case studies of classroom use. The goal is to understand both students' learning of computational thinking and how to bridge the formal and informal learning via classroom implementation of the Zoombinis game.

por.por_cntn:
The project Zoombinis: The Full Development Implementation Research Study of a Computational Thinking Game for Upper Elementary and Middle School Learners studied the educational impact of the award-winning educational computer game Zoombinis on students’ computational thinking (CT). When TERC re-released the popular logic puzzle game for desktops and mobile devices in 2015, CT was just taking hold in the US curriculum.  

 

Our research team studied CT practices in 45 classes across the US that were using Zoombinis as an instructional tool in grades 3-8. Teachers used the game, along with a suite of activities, to support CT in their classroom. Our study focused on four CT practices we argue are core to all of CT and are clearly observable in Zoombinis gameplay. These four CT practices are:

  • Problem Decomposition: When approaching a complex problem, learners decompose, or break, it into manageable parts and then tackle one part at a time.
  • Pattern Recognition: Learners look for patterns within and across problems or tasks. Pattern Recognition is required for all kinds of sorting and classification tasks, for example, as well as seeing trends in data and other forms of information.
  • Abstraction: Learners abstract, or generalize, rising above the details and seeing the rules that can be applied generally to other situations.
  • Algorithm Design: Learners may express an algorithm, a sequence of instructions or steps required to solve a problem or accomplish a task.

 

This research had two primary goals:

  • To establish the validity of game-based learning assessments that used educational data mining (EDM) detectors to measure CT practices in the gameplay, and
  • To understand the teaching and gameplay conditions that promoted the development of CT practices in Zoombinis classrooms.

 

Teachers kept and shared records of their classroom activities related to Zoombinis and CT during the study period, dedicating at least 10 hours of class-time to these activities. We collected these records, along with data logs from each students’ gameplay and characteristic data about students and classes (e.g. demographics and grade level). Early in our study, teachers reported students who typically struggled academically were excelling in CT with Zoombinis, so we also retrospectively collected the IEP (Individualized Education Program) status of students in a sub-sample of consenting classes.

 

To build automated detectors of CT from the gameplay data logs, we first observed a wide range of players and conducted extensive coding of gameplay, identifying patterns of play related to the four CT practices. Two researchers coded the observations independently and refined the coding system until we could reliably obtain high levels of agreement between researchers. We then used EDM methods to build automated detectors that could confidently predict the same CT practices directly from the gameplay data logs in a replicable and scalable manner. The resulting automated detectors were then used as embedded implicit assessments of CT.

 

For each research participant, we studied their CT practices as measured by theses embedded implicit assessments, while also collect external pre/post assessment data about their CT practices in general (outside the game). Because CT as a focus in education is such a young field, there were few validated assessment tools to use as pre/post measures for this age range, and the ones that did exist were largely textual or coding-based, which could have presented extraneous barriers for some learners. Thus, we worked with psychometricians and game designers to develop a set of online logic puzzles called Interactive Assessments of Computational Thinking (IACT). We ran validation studies of these assessments with both the Zoombinis research sample and another sample of 2,333 students in grades 3-8, from a small school district we worked with on another project. We found moderate validity for IACT to measure an overall set of CT practices, but IACT was not reliable to measure each individual CT practice separately. Therefore we used the overall measure of CT as an outcome measure of CT.

 

We compared the results of the IACT assessments to the CT practices revealed by the automated detectors. The detectors were significant predictors of the IACT post-assessment scores and thus show promise as implicit assessments of CT practices within gameplay. The study also showed students who played the game longer and who demonstrated more CT practices in the game scored highest on IACT post-assessments, when accounting for pre-assessment scores. Finally, the results from the sub-study of classes with known IEP status suggest a CT performance gap was reduced in classes that used higher amounts of Zoombinis and accompanying classroom activities. The sub-sample, however, was quite small (12 classes with only a few students in most classes with IEP status), so further research in this area is needed before generalizing this finding.
